content: <@1242765652297650288> Does claude code see the porjects / convos from claude web
author: moofadoofa#0

content:
Unfortunately not; there is a chrome extension though that allows you to take an entire chat in the web and export it in different formats, you can use that and send it to claude code. I've done this a few times with decent success. 

Don't wanna post the link here just in case that's frowned upon considering extensions are known for security issues, but I have it installed in Brave browser for months with no issue.
It's called "Claude Exporter: Save Claude as PDF, MD and more"
author: exiled.dev#0

content: Supports outputs: csv, image, json, text, markdown, pdf. And you can select the whole conversation, just assistant messages or just user messages. It's pretty nifty
author: exiled.dev#0

content: I often start with story ideas in web, and move them to claude code later using this method. I always have claude deconstruct the turns into a new file/format though, just to remove any junk data
author: exiled.dev#0

content: hi
author: vampygirl699#0

content:
Hey everyone! I have a couple of suggestions for improving the Claude.ai chat interface, specifically for Projects:
1. "Select All" checkbox for project files
When working with projects that have many files, it would be really helpful to have a "Select All" checkbox to include all files in the conversation at once. Currently, you have to click each file individually, which is tedious. I actually had to write my own browser extension to work around this.
2. Replace file option
It would be great to have the ability to replace a file in a project directly, instead of having to delete it and re-upload a new version.
That's it - thanks for reading!

author: brian.edwards#0

content: The Ralph Wiggum technique originated from Jeffrey Huntley as a simple bash loop that kept re-prompting Claude until tasks were complete, and Anthropic later released an official ralph-wiggum plugin for Claude Code . The technique works by using a Stop hook that intercepts Claude‚Äôs exit attempts and creates a self-referential feedback loop, preventing Claude from ending sessions until it outputs a specific completion promise . The plugin enables autonomous development loops where each iteration adds context from previous attempts, allowing Claude to learn from failures automatically without human intervention . Critics note that Anthropic‚Äôs official implementation can be fragile, dying in cryptic ways and missing the original technique‚Äôs key insight of carving work into independent context windows rather than just running forever . The Ralph technique‚Äôs viral popularity in late December 2025 and early January 2026 coincided with Anthropic cracking down on third-party tools like OpenCode that were using subscription OAuth tokens to access Claude outside official channels .
author: brian.edwards#0

content: https://www.humanlayer.dev/blog/brief-history-of-ralph
